verses.text: Listen to my prayer, O God; do not hide yourself from my supplication.
verses.comment: This opening echoes Psalms where the psalmist calls for God not to turn away. The directness reflects trust in God's presence, foundational to personal prayer in Catholic tradition.

verses.text: Attend to me and answer me; I am restless in my complaint and I groan.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s honesty about inner turmoil invites Catholics to confidently seek God’s comfort through prayer, as in the practice of the Liturgy of the Hours.

verses.text: Because of the voice of the enemy, because of the oppression of the wicked. For they bring suffering upon me and in anger they harbor hostility against me.
verses.comment: Enmity and oppression often symbolize spiritual struggle, which early Christian commentators saw pointing toward Christ’s persecution.

verses.text: My heart convulses within me, and the terrors of death have fallen upon me.
verses.comment: Strong language of anguish points prophetically to Jesus in Gethsemane (see Matt. 26:38), prefigured in the psalms.

verses.text: Fear and trembling come over me, and horror has overwhelmed me.
verses.comment: The repeated references to terror are both literal (David’s plight) and spiritual (the cost of discipleship and the conversion of soul in Catholic understanding).

verses.text: And I said, 'Oh, that I had wings like a dove! I would flee away and find rest.'
verses.comment: Desire to escape troubles points to the soul’s yearning for heavenly peace, linking Catholic eschatological hope.

verses.text: Surely, I would wander far away; I would lodge in the wilderness. Selah.
verses.comment: 'Wilderness' is commonly a place of spiritual seeking and solitude in Catholic ascetic practice.

verses.text: I would hurry to find shelter from the raging wind and storm.
verses.comment: The 'shelter' recalls Christ calming the storm, symbolizing the Church as refuge.

verses.text: Confuse, O Lord, divide their tongues; for I see violence and strife in the city.
verses.comment: Reference to Babel predicting division; Catholic unity as remedy is subtly implied.

verses.text: Day and night they go around it on its walls, and trouble and mischief are within it.
verses.comment: City here points literally to Jerusalem, but spiritually to the soul encircled by temptation—a theme in Catholic spiritual writings.

verses.text: Destruction is within it; oppression and deceit do not depart from its streets.
verses.comment: The persistence of sin foreshadows the need for ongoing grace through the sacraments, a Catholic view on sanctification.

verses.text: For it is not an enemy who taunts me— then I could bear it; it is not an adversary who rises against me— then I could hide from him.
verses.comment: The pain from a close friend’s betrayal evokes Judas’s betrayal of Christ, a clear type and anti-type linkage.

verses.text: But it is you, a man, my equal, my companion and my close friend.
verses.comment: Emphasizes intimacy of betrayal. Catholic tradition reads this as foreshadowing Christ’s passion.

verses.text: We used to take sweet counsel together; within God’s house we walked in harmony.
verses.comment: 'God's house' suggests liturgical worship, a key Catholic reference to the importance of communal prayer and the Eucharist.

verses.text: Let death steal upon them; let them go down alive to the grave; for wickedness is in their dwellings, in their hearts.
verses.comment: Echoes Korah’s rebellion—the serious consequences of betrayal and division. Subtly points to Catholic teachings on grave sin and its effects.

verses.text: But I call to God, and the LORD will save me.
verses.comment: God’s saving act is both immediate and ultimate—a Catholic vision of salvation through Christ, especially in the Church.

verses.text: Evening, morning, and at noon I utter my complaint and moan, and He hears my voice.
verses.comment: Prayer at set times echoes the Catholic tradition of structured daily prayers (Liturgy of the Hours).

verses.text: He redeems my soul in peace from the battle that they wage against me, for many are arrayed against me.
verses.comment: Redemption and peace through God are strongly fulfilled in Christ. Catholic theology sees this completed in Christ’s death, resurrection, and ongoing mediation.

verses.text: God will hear and humble them— He who is enthroned of old— because they do not change, nor do they fear God. Selah.
verses.comment: God’s eternal sovereignty recalls Christ’s kingship; 'do not change' references steadfastness, desired in Catholic virtue.

verses.text: My companion has put forth his hands against his friends; he has violated his covenant.
verses.comment: Violation of covenant reflects the deep wounding of betrayal, which is healed sacramentally in Catholic confession.

verses.text: His speech was smooth as butter, yet war was in his heart; his words were softer than oil, yet they were drawn swords.
verses.comment: Hypocrisy in words versus actions is a key insight; Catholic tradition encourages examination of conscience.

verses.text: Cast your burden on the LORD, and He will sustain you; He will never let the righteous be shaken.
verses.comment: Divine support of the righteous; Catholics are invited to entrust fears to God, encouraged especially at Mass.

verses.text: But You, O God, will bring them down to the pit of destruction; men of blood and treachery shall not live out half their days. But I will trust in You.
verses.comment: Final contrast of judgment and trust. Catholic interpretation sees the certainty of justice balanced with trust in God’s mercy.
